abstract.text: Initiate a request for identity information by prompting a user for permission and decrypting a response payload.

metadata.title: Requesting identity data from a Wallet pass

inlineContent.text: The Wallet app allows people to store a state identification card, mobile driver’s license (mDL), or national identification card from a government issuing authority, such as the department of motor vehicles. These documents are between a person and the issuing authority — Apple doesn’t create or see the documents.

Beginning on iPhone with iOS 16, you can request information from IDs in Wallet to verify a person’s age or identity. If a person accepts the request, the system gets the information from their issuing authority and your app receives a payload. After decryption, the payload contains data that follows the ISO 18013-5 specification. To use the elements your app requests, send the payload to your server for verification.
For design guidance, see

This API only works on iPhone and returns an error if you access it on iPad. It requires a special entitlement from Apple. Building an app with this entitlement requires macOS 13 or later. For more information about the entitlement, see
Before you request information from an ID in Wallet, you create an object to describe the elements you need. Your app can only request the elements your entitlement grants. Create a
if you’re requesting information from a person’s state or mobile driver’s license. Create a
if you’re requesting information from their national identificaton card, and add the elements to the request.
For each element, you specify your intent to store the resulting data by using
, or
. Upon request, the system presents the information for a person to review in a system sheet.
The framework allows for requesting the Boolean

An app can’t include both an

inlineContent.text: To create an identity request, you need the merchant identifier you configure in the developer portal. A merchant identifier never expires, and you can use the same one that you use for Apple Pay.
A request also needs a
to prevent your server from using a response document more than once. Your server needs the
to decrypt the response document, so generate it there and associate it with the user’s session.

code: request.nonce = // The nonce your server generates.

inlineContent.text: Your app’s
file needs to provide a message for the
key. If this key is missing, any attempt to request a document fails.
When requesting a document, the system presents a sheet to the user to confirm the request before retrieving any data. If the user rejects the request, your app receives a
error.
When you receive a
, you’re ready to verify the request payload. The data in the
property isn’t readable on the device, so you need to send it to your server for verification.
The elements in
map to a set of elements in the ISO and American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators (AAMVA) namespaces in the response. For
, the elements map to a set of elements in the ISO and JP namespace in the response. For a list of elements, see
and
Only one request can be in progress at a time. Otherwise, the system returns a
error.
To learn more about verifying identity requests, see

Even if you don’t live in an area that supports IDs in Wallet, you can test your implementation through the iPhone simulator or by downloading a developer profile on your local device. When you request a document, you receive a mock mDL that’s similar to a real ID. When you test with the simulator, the response doesn’t include a real issuing authority or device signature. The developer test profile produces a real device signature, but not a real issuer signature. A mock mDL isn’t visible in the Wallet app, so don’t treat it as real. To activate a mock mDL on your device, download the Wallet identity developer profile from

abstract.text: Decrypt and verify an in-app presentment request on your server.
Process Apple Pay payments in your app, and create and distribute passes for the Wallet app.
An object that presents a sheet that prompts the user to allow a request for identity information.
Returns whether an identity document is available to request.
An object that displays a button to trigger the identity verification flow.
An object that represents the response to a request.
An encrypted data object that contains the document information and metadata to associate with a request.
An object for requesting information from a user’s driver’s license or equivalent document.
An object that represents the elements an app requests from identity documents.
An element that represents the user’s age, in years.
Returns an element that represents the user’s age is at least the age you specify.
An error that indicates the user cancels the presented sheet.
An error that indicates a request is already in progress.
An object that indicates your app may store a data element for an indefinite length of time.
An object that indicates your app may store a data element for the length of time you specify.
An object that indicates your app won’t store a data element any longer than necessary to complete a request.
An object for requesting information from a user’s national ID card.
An object that represents a request for identity information from a Wallet pass.
An arbitrary number that the signed response playload includes.
A view that displays a button for identity verification.
A type that represents the label you use with a verify identity button.
A type that represents the style you use with a verify identity button.
Decrypt and verify an in-app presentment request on your server.
Manage tickets, boarding passes, payment cards and other passes in the Wallet app.
